Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This research is aimed at generating polymer surfaces with novel or improved function by an approach that insures compositional economy and facile, conventional processing. Desired surface functions will be generated via a modifier that spontaneously concentrates at the surface based on synthetic approaches to be used in this project. The focus will be modification of soft polymer surfaces, including polyurethanes and silicones. Such research is challenging because of high nanoscale mobility for near-surface polymer chains that can drive phase separation and negate surface modification. Recently, a new hybrid bottlebrush-nanoglass (BB-NG) strategy has resulted in restriction of near-surface modifier chain mobility. Thus, BB-NG surface modification will be a primary focus of future research. Preliminary results with a modified polyurethane system indicate stable surface-concentrated quaternary charge. Zeta potentials are being investigated to test the limits of charge stability. Another result suggests broad applicability for BB-NG modifiers. BB-NG modification for a hybrid fluorooxetane system led to an unexpected self-layered soft surface/ tough bulk. This unusual compositional stratification will be the subject of further research, as initial results show very low ice adhesion. Potential applications include coatings for wind turbines and power lines. Finally, new ways to introduce surface function into silicones will be explored that also involve balancing desired surface function and near-surface phase separation.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This research is aimed at introducing special surface properties into conventional polymers that are commonly encountered in coated or molded objects. For example, incorporating a small amount of surface modifier is leading to coatings with combinations of desirable properties such as oil and water resistance as well as easy release of ice. Such coatings may have applications for coating power lines, airplane wings and wind turbine blades. Broader impacts of this research will include interdisciplinary training and curriculum development. Another impact is the participation of underrepresented minorities in the research program by collaboration with Virginia State University. On a national level, support for this research will facilitate K-12 leadership activities that bring new knowledge to high school and secondary school teachers who, in turn, will incorporate this knowledge into classroom science instruction. Internationally, collaborative activities with Japan and Italy have led to productive student exchanges and will continue through this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fundamental innovations have led to exciting advances in polymer surface science that will have a favorable impact on our daily lives and will lead to new opportunities for employment by virtue of transitioning findings to industry.

1. It is well known that ice accumulation during winter causes damage or has disruptive effects on communication wires, wind turbine blades, trains and even automobiles (windshields).  Less well known are the effects of icing (safety, energy loss) associated with commercial “blast” freezer operations that process much of the food that we eat. Research supported by this grant led to discovering polymeric materials science for coatings and related objects that minimizes adhesion of ice. That is, ice builds up, but poor adhesion results in ice falling off by the force of gravity (Figure 1). This promising work has been translated to “incubator” status with an NSF Small Business Innovative Research grant under which Polymer Exploration Group LLC is developing products for industrial and consumer applications that will enhance operational safety  save energy, provide new consumer products and replace “sledgehammer” methods for removal of ice.

 2. The problem of infections that are acquired in hospitals, nursing homes and similar environments is well known. Articles on “super bugs” are often in the press. Under previous grants and this grant we have created new ways to make plastics and rubbery materials with surfaces that kill bacteria on contact. That is, the coated surface is always sterile. In the last few months of this grant challenges were overcome with the development of an economical way to “overcoat” elastomers or rubbers with a durable thin film that promises to cure existing infections and prevents new infections. While killing bacteria efficiently, this new approach is designed to protect delicate human cells such as those in the urinary tract. Further, antimicrobial efficiency is achieved without “leaching” of antibiotics or other agents to which bacteria can rapidly develop resistance. Importantly, initial evidence suggests that “super bugs” cannot build up resistance to the new technology. This work shows promise for eliminating catheter associated urinary tract infections, which account for 70% of hospital-acquired infections and often lead to more serious illnesses. The promise of this pioneering effort has been recognized by the National Institutes of Health. A Phase I SBIR project at Polymer Exploration Group LLC is scheduled to begin in summer 2015. If successful, an entirely new way to eliminate infections will impact the lives of our loved ones who are in a health care environment.  

The “hands on” research that led to the results described above was performed by a research group that emphasizes education of minorities at the undergraduate and graduate levels (Figure 2). Ph.D. students trained on this grant have gone to coveted positions in government (Institute for Defense Analysis) and industry (DuPont, Intel). Findings under this grant were the subject of 14 publications and two patent applications.

National and international leadership was demonstrated by invited lectures and by the organization of specialist meetings. Based largely on research activities supported by this and previous NSF grants, the principle investigator was named Fellow, American Chemical Society in 2009 and was appointed Commonwealth Professor in 2010 (there are two such professorships among 60 faculty in the VCU School of Engineering).
